subtitle: seems like we've taken the normal
everyday life struggles that people have
gone through for decades now and turn
them into a mental illness I agree with
that to a great extent yeah I think uh
just the number of diagnosis is you know
skyrocketed in the past 30 40 years with
each new DSM and it's not I mean I I
think that having markers having general
descriptors of what people are
experiencing is useful but not to not to
pathologize it so much and I think most
depression uh is due to the fact that
people aren't living the kind of lives
that they want to live it's not because
of the biological imbalance even the
psychiatric Community is getting away
from the whole idea of depression being
a biological imbalance of Serotonin
dopamine things of that nature it's just
not that simple there's a small uh part
of the population I think that where
that applies to I think it definitely
applies to to certain uh experiences
like bipolar or schizophrenia but even
even those it's you know it's a human

Experience that's important
